year.

the other. It might be easier to move the whole planet closer to the Sun 
instead (sure some "genius" will come on that idea)

comments.text:
Yes, it could be, but it would be extremely difficult. First of all, 
there's the moral and ethical implications of slamming asteroids into 
something so vital to our planet's workings, but assuming we could safely 
do that, it's just the start of the problems.

The Moon has such little gravity, and is so close to a planet with much 
greater gravitational pull, that we would have to have some kind of system 
to replenish the atmosphere. If we expect people to live on the Moon, then 
we can't slam asteroids into it on a regular basis, so we're going to have 
to come up with a better way.

One way would be to created a moon-wide dome that would keep the atmosphere 
in. It would have the added benefit of being able to squeeze down, adding 
pressure to the surface of Luna and allowing us to live comfortably on it. 
The engineering for designing such a structure isn't far off, but the 
logistics of creating a dome, and the material science needed to make it 
light and strong enough, is well out of our grasp.

Additionally, Luna doesn't have a magnetic field, so we'd also need to 
build protection against solar radiation, which again could be addressed by 
some kind of massive dome. 

Luna would be a beautiful place if terraformed, though. Most of the dray 
land would be on the far side of the moon, so you would have spectacular 
views of the sky at night. By the way, nights would last for two weeks, and 
days would as well, so that would take some getting used to. Also, the Moon 
would become more reflective, so we'd see a much brighter Moon from Earth.
comments.author: Lutranereis

comments.text:
+Mr Ferario I have a theory! My theory is that aliens a long time ago were 
fighting an intergalactic war in some nearby galaxy. When that war was 
going on they were on the brink of total annihilation, so, they sent 
colonists to other galaxies to survive the war. Earth was picked to be 
terra-formed or it was already to be the savior of their kind. Why they 
picked earth? Well for starters its in another galaxy, we have an ort cloud 
around our entire solar system protecting us and 2 planets that could be 
colonized. I'm guessing they colonized Mars first and their body structure 
started to change making them look more human like. It is to believe a 
nuclear war killed all life on mars due to past high radiation that has 
died off in the atmosphere. This is how Mars magnetosphere broke. So as a 
last resort they went to earth and barely made it crash landing their, 
losing all the equipment they came with. So they had to start from scratch 
and earths environment overtime made them into the humans they are 
today(This is after the dinosaurs disappeared). They didn't share their 
information about Mars or anything that happened previously to protect 
their last chance of hope. Why didn't they share their information? The 
enemy aliens might find technology that matches our ancestor aliens and 
think this is a colony and destroy it. I believe that if we colonize Mars 
once again we might find some remnants of an early intelligent civilization 
of a pre-meta human being. This is my theory. Enjoy!

comments.text:
+Mickey G
The problem with solar winds is that they mess with the structure of 
organic compounds. The wavelength of the radiation is so low the waves can 
travel into molecules, tearing them apart. The only way to prevent the 
winds from being a problem would be to induce rotation of Mars's core, 
which would be rather difficult.
comments.author: Max Thomas

comments.text:
+Max Thomas Many species of bacteria, including a lot of cyanobacteria are 
very resistant to radiation, enough amount of kill off most animals. 
Genetically engineered plants is capable of surviving in the Mars' solar 
radiation level. Alternatively, thaw the polar cap on Mars first to create 
ocean, then dump several species of cyanobacteria into the water, the 
oxygen production doesn't have to start on land, in fact, most of the 
oxygen we breath in today was created underwater by these photosynthetic 
bacteria.
comments.author: Mickey G

comments.text:
+Zachary De Rosia I'm not egging you on (the double post was just something 
weird with YouTube), I just don't think that there is enough evidence to 
say that life came to Earth on a comet or meteor. I also don't consider 
VSauce or SciShow to be evidence. I consider peer reviewed scientific 
papers which contain actual unique research to be evidence, and I haven't 
seen any papers which support that any more than any other hypothesis. All 
the research I have seen has concluded that amino acids or other "building 
blocks of life" could survive on a comet, but we also know that those same 
"building blocks" could emerge and survive on earth, so none of them have 
found anything that suggests one hypothesis is more viable than the other. 
Until we find evidence one way or the other, I prefer to stick with "I 
don't know" as an answer. I'm really not trying to antagonize you, I was 
actually hoping that you had something interesting so that I could go look 
at it. Sorry if I sound like a dick.
comments.author: ArchGamer

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Donald Timpson, so apparently you can just spout a bit of obviousness and 
call yourself a pro. Here's the enormous loopholes in that bit of 
nonsense...

  I feel like we all should know, I wasn't speaking of Earth as a separate, 
living creature as a whole, so thanks for clarifying the fact you can't 
hurt dirt. Also, I never denied the food-chain. It exists for the balance. 
I believe I stated we eat too much protein than what nature intended 
(again, nature not being our mommy).

  As far as the bacteria argument... really? Maybe I am saying we are equal 
to the bacteria that thrive on our skin, maybe I'm not. But cleaning (as 
you'll find in nature) is natural.

revolution. I feel like you may have proven my point with that one. We make

comments.author: Donald Timpson

comments.text:
+jhkauhi First off, we can live on earth. We do it every day. Shocker, I 
know. Second, the earth exists independent of us and all other life. We 
could slam the moon into the earth, and it would be fine (turns out you 
can't hurt dirt). The worst thing we can do is make it less inhabitable for 
ourselves (either directly or indirectly). You can play the "all life is 
equal" card, but following that logic, stop eating. You consume much more 
than one life by existing, in fact you kill millions of bacteria by just 
cleaning. Human life is superior.
     Since the industrial age, we have FLOURISHED! Life expectancy has 
increased drastically, and both population and technology are increasing 
exponentially! Technology will continue to make the earth more inhabitable 
for us, and help us continue to flourish here, and eventually, on other 
planets as well. You can speculate about the effects our lifestyle will 
have on the planet 200 years from now, but thanks to technology and humans, 
me and you can probably talk about that 200 years from now.
     Now let's pretend that evolution could care; we are still it's 
greatest accomplishment. It would be proud. It has finally created a 
species that no longer needs to evolve, can comprehend it's own existence, 
and lives drastically better than it did 2000 years ago. In fact, it 
created a species that not only overcame the challengers of the earth's 
environment, but that can also consider living on other planets. This is 
incredible!
     Don't pretend your deep by saying stuff like "why can't we all just 
love each other, and all life, and treat the earth right". It's obvious the 
several benefits to colonizing beyond our own planet, which would include 
terraforming Mars.
comments.author: Donald Timpson

captions.text:
This DNews episode is brought to you by Domain
Dot Com!

What if you could live on Mars and not wear
a spacesuit. Welcome to the world of terraforming!

Hey spacefarers, it's Trace! Thanks for watching
DNews. Terraforming is the combination of

the latin terra -- or earth, and forming.
Which… you probably know what forming means.

It describes the process of converting an
alien planet to be more Earth-like. The idea

would be to make a planet able to support
human life without a spacesuit. To actually

PERFORM the process could take decades or
even centuries, assuming it would even be
possible.

Mars is the golden boy for terraformation.
It's a good size, not too far from the sun,

and has a minor atmosphere, if a thin one.
If you were to stand on Mars as you're dressed

now, at the equator, at midday, in the Martian
summer -- it would be a warm 80 degrees (27

C), but that's about it for the win. In the
winter, it can get to almost minus 200 (-128C)

at night. Not to mention, Mars has no atmospheric
pressure to speak of, so your blood would

boil, your organs would rupture, and there's
no oxygen so you wouldn't be able to breathe.

No bueno. Its near-vacuum atmosphere is mostly
CO2 with a tiny bit of nitrogen. By contrast,

Earth is mainly nitrogen, a tiny bit of of
CO2 and 20 percent oxygen. But all that aside,
let's assume terraforming is possible.

Getting down to brass tacks, what exactly
do we need to do to terraform the Red Planet?

We need to cut UV, raise the temperature and
pressure, introduce water and fix the atmosphere
to make it Earth-like.

There are three major theories on how to do
this. Theory One: use orbiting mirrors the

size of Lake Michigan to reflect sunlight
and heat the surface. Point these impossibly

large mirrors at the polar ice caps to melt
them, releasing CO2 trapped in the ice. Thicker

atmosphere will hold in more heat from the
sun. Then we just have to find some oxygen

and nitrogen, maybe by breaking up the H2O?
Theory Two: use greenhouse-gas producing factories

to build an atmosphere. (Kid Trace thought
of this too) We're already accidentally doing

it to Earth, so we know the technology exists!
More greenhouse gas equals warmer planet,

polar ice caps melt, from there it's the same
as One. Theory Three: smash icy comets into
Mars.

The last one is my favorite for two reasons,
Theory One requires 200,000 pound mirrors

to be built in space. Nope. Theory Two requires
us to build factories on Mars, which is ludicrously

expensive and WILL contaminate the Martian
environment with human bacteria. It is ALL

OVER US ALL THE TIME. Once infected the bacteria
could mutate and really screw up our planet
baby.

If you saw my recent video called, "Why Is
There Air," you might remember that Earth

was hit by a bunch of icy comets, distributing
water and minerals on our infant planet. The

impacts thickened the atmosphere and heated
us up. If we can do this for Mars too, then

we can create a terraformed Mars without introducing
potentially invasive bacteria onto the surface.

I love that. According to HowStuffWorks, one
fantastically large asteroid impact could

raise the temperature on Mars by 3 Celsius.
This would melt a trillion gallons of water,

thicken the atmosphere and have the added
bonus of introducing oxygen too.

Of course, any atmospheric modifications we
made to Mars would slowly spin off into space

thanks to the solar wind's erosion and low
gravity. If done properly, metallic asteroids

could be mixed with our thrown comets… A
2008 study from University of Toronto theorizes

that's how the Martian core got a magnetosphere
in the first place, it might be we just need
to restart it.

So, let's say we're able to travel to the
asteroid belt, grab some giant space rocks,

fix little nuclear engines on them which propel
them on a collision course with Mars. Then
what?

Then we introduce genetically engineered soil
bacteria, algae, plants and other oxygen and

carbon dioxide cycle generating life to try
to make the biosphere habitable, and eventually…

like centuries or millennia later -- we'd
have a blue Mars. Assume we didn't screw it
up somehow, because there are no second chances.

In the end, if it worked, humans on Mars could
stand outside and breathe the air, they'd

have less gravity to content with, so they'd
have to figure that one out -- human bodies

don't do well with low gravity, and hopefully
they'd have figured out how to avoid the GLOBAL

STORMS that come up sometimes during the Martian
year. But hey, shrug, this is the future we're

talking about, maybe they'll be able to do
anything?

Do you want to know more about terraforming?
I know this was a big episode, so let me know

if you've still got questions and I'll do
a follow up.

Thanks for watching DNews, fill up the comments
section with your thoughts on terraforming

and controlling a whole planet. In the meantime,
for more manageable control, why not just

start a website? Go to Domain Dot Com and
grab a URL and make a website. No domain extension

will help you tell your story like a DOT COM
or DOT NET domain name. Go to Domain dot come

and grab a domain name and use the coupon
code DNEWS for 15 percent off!

title: How We Can Live On Mars Without A Spacesuit
